question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: This is a very fun class, but its also very hands on and engaging. The coursework is not difficult and is mostly projects that you need to complete mostly outside of class. Be prepared to spend quite a few hours working in the foundry on projects, and be prepared to work with a team that you're stuck with for that project, for better or worse. It's still a very fun class, but the small size means you can't simply coast by, you have to engage with the class and play an active role in the projects. Great professor, and its a good opportunity to get to know your fellow CEE community.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- matrix algebra
- coding
- problem solving

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I relearned matrix algebra and then learned how to use matrices to analyze structures by hand and by code.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course connects the material taught in EGR 201 to the level of analysis required for more advanced structural analysis. How to use finite element methods to analyze the reactions in bars, beams, and frames in 2D. How to translate the calculations on paper to code for analysis.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned to analyze bars, beams, and frames. I learned how to efficiently use Matlab to analyze these structures and solve them by hand. As well as understanding the general procedure for determining reactions, element forces, etc.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to analyze a bar, beam, and frame connectivity system through matrix analysis. I am able to distinguish between different force loads acting on any given element, including but not limited to, axial, shear, and moment forces.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to address bar and beam deformation due to axial and transverse loadings. I learned about how bar deformation changes due to rotations. Finally, I learned how both bar and beam deformations come together in addressing frames.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to use matrices analyze the structural components of bars, beams, and frames for the different kinds of connections regardless of the element's orientation. I also learned how to compute these components in Matlab.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I liked the review day before each exam. That was very helpful.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: In-class lectures were thoughtful and in-depth; the recitation period helped ensure understanding of homework and code, and the detailed home gave good examples of what was expected on the exams.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The professor was very accessible via Ed Discussion, email, office hours, etc. The short surveys about the level of understanding that were given before exams were helpful in prompting reflection on my level of understanding of the material. Definitely keep the review of the previous lecture and the outlining of objectives at the beginning of each lecture.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Our instructor was able to structure the course in a way that made it helpful to understand the concepts. He has an outline of our objectives for the beginning of the class, as well as a summary of the last class that helped me feel like there was a nice flow between lectures. Then we would learn the concepts and always go through a detailed example of the type of problem we learned.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: The instructor was readily available to answer questions and meet out of scheduled class times to help students understand the material. The component that I most appreciated throughout the semester were the brief summaries of the previous lecture at the beginning of a new lecture. Most often than not, I was able to connect the dots and retain the information relating each lecture through the summaries. I believe this method would be helpful with every course!

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Summary of the previous lecture before class was helpful. I think drawing out the big picture and how everything fits into each other is also something that helped my understanding.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the handwritten notes so that I had time to copy everything down on my iPad/paper. I also really liked how the notes related to each exam were printed out for us to use and mark up, and that these could be used during the exams.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I enjoyed going through the derivations for each process that we were learning, but the lines between what was a derivation and what was a part of the problem-solving method often became blurry during lectures and caused me to struggle during application. I didn't like when the class was asked to attempt to apply the derivation immediately after learning it and without a full example (preferably multiple) of the process being done. I think a lot of time was wasted because half of the class knew what was going on and half didn't. We could have spent that time going over an example problem so the entire class felt comfortable with the process before trying one on their own.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: It was interesting that a whole structure can be represented by a matrix.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: What made this class intellectually stimulating was the new way in which it taught me to think about analyzing systems.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Showing the connections from the bar to beam to frame gave me a deeper understanding of the material. Having more real-life examples/problems may make it easier to connect to CEE423L, such as having a project where students look at a real structure of their choice and identify the nodes and different supports and then put together the k matrix for a portion of that structure. A real-world project would make the content feel less theoretical.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Learning how to use Matlab and understanding the correlation between the code and the problems were intellectually stimulating.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Understanding the matrix analysis of a bar, beam, or frame system compared to a mechanistic approach, as learned in EGR 201, made me realize that a complicated structure could be analyzed quickly and accurately.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: This class was stimulating because it builds off of my previous knowledge of EGR 201 and MATH 218. It could have been a bit more stimulating if there was time in class (during the first week of class or so) to review some basic principles of both of those courses, or at least the principles directly related to what we needed to know for this course. That would've allowed me more time to get adjusted to this course without having to jump straight in, since it has been a year since I'd taken EGR 201 and over a year since I'd taken MATH 218.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: Recitation could've been more stimulating as i felt like I was just copying down whatever the TA wrote (which wasn't a full solution), without having time to actually process what we were analyzing.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Ask the professor a lot of questions he is good at answering them.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I highly recommend the course; Dr. G is incredibly nice and patient with those who are having difficulty understanding the material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Dr. Guilleminot is a very understanding professor and wants you to succeed! Take advantage of the resources available to you and show up to class and you will do well. A thorough understanding of this material is needed for future classes in civil engineering, so make sure you take the time to really learn the material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would tell them to review EGR 201, MATH 353, and MATH 218-D2. To succeed in the class you have to make time, or have time dedicated outside of class to absorb/understand the material.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: I would recommend that students ask questions when they are confused because the material on the course builds upon itself substantially. Indeed, bar, beam, and frame systems are all analyzed using the same methodology, with slight variations. If a student is confused with the bar system, they most certainly will be confused with the beam system. If a student is confused with the beam system, they most certainly will be confused with the frame system. The instructor does a great job in clarifying confusion, but the student must ask the question first.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Go to office hours/recitation and ask questions if you are stuck. The material builds on the fundamental concepts you learn early in the course, so making sure you understand it as soon as possible is very important.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?

Additionally, it would be helpful to have context about the successes and failings of water resource engineering in the past. Not just dam breaks but how dams affect the ecosystem. The instructor referenced the fact that lots of dams are being decommissioned currently but there was no mention of the opposition to dams, the history of levee failure in the US, or other context to disputed methods of water resources. It feels important that engineers are educated about the past so that they do not blindly repeat previous historical mistakes. This is particularly important in this course because of the self-worsening issue of flooding that has been perpetuated in the past by poor engineering choices.

question_text: What made this class stimulating or how could it be more intellectually stimulating if it wasn’t?
response_text: I think this course was pretty intellectually stimulating for how much new content was strictly math. I do think the most exciting parts of this course were taught at the end of the semester when we could learn more about the applications of what we learned. Specifically learning about habitat restoration potential and how to direct the flow of water amongst desertification was incredible. It was especially interesting because most of the exposure to CEE at Duke is through wastewater treatment or air quality, so getting to learn about other applications and other career opportunities was very encouraging.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text:
Homework: The homework was structured very nicely in the way the a lot of the code, concepts, and work built off each other every week. I also appreciated that we were getting the opportunity to code our own FEM from scratch because now I have grown to have a good understanding of how these things work. I appreciate also you going through the homework at the beginning of lecture to get us thinking about the problems. 
Lectures: I would say that the lectures slides were dense in good material, this has pros and cons, but the pro was that I could always come back to the slides and have all the information for me there. I also enjoyed the recaps of the previous lecture. I also felt that the strongest lectures were the ones were we went into talking about the shape functions, quadrature points, and algorithms, because I could really visualize the goal with this concepts (for us to build an FEM code). 
Office Hours + Questions: The professor always did a great job at answering questions after class or through emails. They were always nice and helpful. Also shoutout to the TA from Thursday 4-5PM they were a big part in my success in this class.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Be aware that this course is perhaps 85% math, 15% algorithm design; I would not peg this as a standard engineering course, more so a course about a mathematical framework which is very useful to engineering. You certainly don't need to take this to use industrial FEA software - but this course is foundationally important for anyone aiming to do research in finite elements. I highly recommend it.

question_text: What would you like to say about this course to a student who is considering taking it in the future?
response_text: Understand that the math behind the application is very dense and that if you lack both a background in coding and mathematics it is likely you will struggle with the course content. Having a background in either one however, makes the course manageable and achievable. There is almost no busywork and all applications directly contribute to your learning.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned how to conduct a mass balance and how to approach determining the transport of contaminants throughout various environmental systems, including soil and water.
2. I learned the Navier-Stokes Equation and the Advective-Diffusion equation, helping to describe how fluid and chemical contaminants flow within systems.
3. I learned how to better critically think and how to better dissect questions to understand what was given and what was to be found.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course covers the core concepts of mass balances, reaction kinetics, and momentum and mass transport. We looked at systems as either complete-mix or plug-flow, or an intermediate such as complete-mix in series or plug-flow with dispersion. We also covered laminar and turbulent fluid flow and its impact on mass transport.

response_text: Thinking critically, learned about mass balances, and turbulent flow

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: This course, while being very challenging for me, taught me a lot of helpful skills. I had a strong background in calculus and differential equations, but this course put that to the test. It was really cool to see how these math classes applied to the environment and their importance to the transport of pollutants. This class made me think in a completely new way and consider all factors that could effect how something moves in the environment. The Advection-Diffusion Equation has popped up in my other classes and in lab research, so it was very helpful to learn about that in particular. This course definitely seemed like a fundamental class for the work I want to do. It even allowed me to have a deeper conversation with a CEO of a consulting company that works in sediment pollutant remediation. I feel as though this course will be invaluable as I move towards a career in environmental engineering.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: I really enjoyed the first half of the class, when Dr. Wiesner derived equations by hand and really slowed down the learning process so we could understand each step of an equation or mass balance. In addition, the homework assignments were challenging, but getting to work closely with other classmates and the TA was really helpful in facilitating critical thinking and bouncing ideas off one another (as would be the case in the "real world"). Although this course was challenging, I can't remember a time I've learned as much as I have in such a short period of time.

response_text: The professor creates a very enjoyable classroom atmosphere, not too strict with students. Both the course and the homework are challenging, and they really test your understanding of the concepts and the problems.

question_text: Reflecting on the overall learning environment of this class, in what ways did the instructor(s) and the structure or components of the course facilitate your learning? Are there specific course components or methods of instruction you’d keep for future years?
response_text: Dr. Wiesner is so knowledgeable and passionate about this topic and that truly shines through his lectures. He was very patient and willing to answer any questions we had. He also was very relatable and understood the difficulty of the course, which helped me to not feel silly for not understanding some of the material the first, second, or even third time around. I really loved his side stories that he would add in as a "break" from deriving equations on the board. I also appreciated that the homework was much more difficult than the exams. This definitely prepared me for the exams in the class and helped me to feel more confident. While I didn't love doing the homework, having problem sets each week kept me engaged in the material and forced me to learn and use it. The TA, Jaleesia, was very helpful as well in the learning process in this class and was always available for help. I also think having the class meet 3 times a week and that it ended a little early helped me to dedicate the time the course demanded and, in the end, I left with more knowledge gained than I was expecting.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. I learned (primarily from exam questions) how topics discussed in class are directly applied to environmental engineering projects and the implications of chemical processes.
2. I learned the conceptual framework around the redox biogeochemistry ladder and why “reducing conditions” can lead to certain redox reactions being dominant within aquatic systems. I’d always been told that methanogenesis was low energy and in very reducing conditions, but never understood why until we learned the concepts of pe and comparing the pe of methanogenesis to the pe of organic carbon respiration.
3. I learned how metals are analyzed for toxicity through the Biotic Ligand Model framework and how various conditions (NOM, pH) can impact metal toxicity.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. A major adjustment I learned how to make in this course was how to critically think and answer difficult questions in ways I had never had to before. For example, the take-home midterm was a challenge for me, because the solutions to the questions weren't intuitive and often caused me to have to go down other avenues to solve the questions that we did not explicitly go over in class. Although it can be a frustrating experience, I understand how important it is to go through that sort of challenge because things will never be as cut-and-dry in the workforce as they may be in classes.
2. Conceptually, I better understood how to connect quantitative environmental parameters (e.g. partitioning coefficients) to qualitative descriptions of how structure can impact environmental fate.
3. As someone who had not had a lot of experience with understanding chemical fate through atmospheric components, this class gave me a good foundation for understanding this field and helped me feel confident to pursue coursework in air quality engineering.

response_text: I learned various topics of uncertainty quantification. Although I could dive into the specific topics that the course covered, I think what I took from the course is that there is various methods that aim to quantify uncertainty, and different steps you need to take to get there, but overall you need to be able to have an understand of what you are doing, why you are doing, and how it works to gain anything useful from it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I had limited knowledge of UQ and often struggled to comprehend the methods presented in articles. The comprehensive content covered in class provided a significant understanding of UQ with a deep exploration of both non-intrusive and intrusive techniques. More importantly, learning how each approach works enhanced my ability to navigate and analyze uncertainty for different engineering phenomena. This class will prove invaluable in broadening my expertise and I'm glad I took it.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Propagation techniques, why assumptions when conducting statistical analysis to create models matter, and how to make a harder problem (potentially 4th dimension) into an easier (1-D problem).

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: I learned how to model uncertainties in computational systems, which is crucial for making reliable predictions in engineering, science, and finance. I also gained hands-on experience with advanced sampling algorithms, which are essential for statistical analysis and simulations. Ultimately, I learned techniques for propagating uncertainties through computational models, which helps in understanding how input uncertainties affect outputs in complex systems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: How to approach a problem in a methodological way, relating theory to practice, and how to extend the deterministic setting to the stochastic counterpart.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Reviewed foundational concepts in probability, learned how to propagate uncertainties in input variables forward through models, and learned some techniques used to simplify/reduce large computations involved with sampling.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text: Through this course, I learned about soil chemistry, soil compositions, and how to use different instrumentation available to Duke students in the context of soil characterization. As a student that has never taken a class focused on soil, it was interesting to learn about what goes on in that area of the environment. It was definitely a new way of thinking for me as we had to consider many aspects of soil to solve chemistry problems. This also was the first class where pE calculations and applications really made sense - even though I've learned about it in almost every chemistry course I have taken.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
Despite my prior experience in developing ML models, I found myself taken aback by gaps in my understanding based on some of the class material which proved more intricate than I had anticipated. However, amidst the struggles, I did manage to extract valuable insights, particularly from the segments that focused on mechanisms of different classical ML models and handling time series data. These sections not only added depth to my knowledge but provided an amazing learning experience. 
My pre-existing bias towards models for image analyses posed a hurdle. This is because image data analysis isn't a routine part of my work, thus comprehending the intricacies of the utility of these models proved to be a daunting task. Nonetheless, credit to David for breaking down the complexity in a way that made sense whenever some of these models generated meaningful outputs during HWs.An unexpected and positive takeaway was using Google Colab for the HWs. Despite being accustomed to Spyder for my ML analyses, Google Colab proved transformative. My proficiency in using Colab increased tremendously which simplified the completion of assignments on time. Consequently, I have since abandoned Spyder and embraced Colab for my research after appreciating its convenience. Overall, while the course presented challenges, it facilitated significant growth in my skill set by introducing me to tools and work flows that will enhance my research efficiency beyond the class requirements. Thanks, Prof. Carlson!!

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Importance of connectivity (permeability and porosity) in determining the geothermal potential of a site
2) Determining the geothermal potential of sites through drilling is an iterative process, requiring extrapolation and analysis of cores. Cores from multiple sites can be useful to map out underground characteristics. 
3) There are two main types of geothermal: heat and energy. Geothermal for heating requires lower geothermal temperatures, while energy generating geothermal requires higher temperature levels.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- How a geothermal drilling operation is deployed and some of the operational challenges are deployed. 
- Well-logging techniques and various methods and instruments to learn about the geothermal potential, including the porosity and permeability, of a focus area.  
- How geothermal systems, with technology advances, can become economically viable in a broad range of applications from electricity generation to district heating. 
- An overall attitude of thinking creatively and from both a micro and macro perspective in learning more about our earth's systems and ways in which we can leverage those systems to provide resources while minimizing adverse impacts to natural systems.

response_text: While the initial segments of the class presented challenges in comprehending the class material, the way the course material was delivered ultimately facilitated my understanding of various omics approaches over time and the progressive nature of the course allowed me to grasp the nuances of the methods. response_text: I would definitely recommend the CEE Seminar to a student. While it is a graduation requirement, I thoroughly enjoyed taking it. I found this seminar to be equally interesting, challenging, and exciting. While some presentations went over my head, most of the speakers did a great job of explaining their overarching goals. It was also helpful to have times for questions after each presentation because it encouraged me to try to think of technical questions while listening, which kept me more engaged in the talk.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1) Importance of connectivity (permeability and porosity) in determining the geothermal potential of a site
2) Determining the geothermal potential of sites through drilling is an iterative process, requiring extrapolation and analysis of cores. Cores from multiple sites can be useful to map out underground characteristics. 
3) There are two main types of geothermal: heat and energy. Geothermal for heating requires lower geothermal temperatures, while energy generating geothermal requires higher temperature levels.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
- How a geothermal drilling operation is deployed and some of the operational challenges are deployed. 
- Well-logging techniques and various methods and instruments to learn about the geothermal potential, including the porosity and permeability, of a focus area.  
- How geothermal systems, with technology advances, can become economically viable in a broad range of applications from electricity generation to district heating. 
- An overall attitude of thinking creatively and from both a micro and macro perspective in learning more about our earth's systems and ways in which we can leverage those systems to provide resources while minimizing adverse impacts to natural systems.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.

question_text: What knowledge, methods, skills, insights, or ways of thinking did you develop in this course? Please describe three specific things you learned.
response_text:
1. A major adjustment I learned how to make in this course was how to critically think and answer difficult questions in ways I had never had to before. For example, the take-home midterm was a challenge for me, because the solutions to the questions weren't intuitive and often caused me to have to go down other avenues to solve the questions that we did not explicitly go over in class. Although it can be a frustrating experience, I understand how important it is to go through that sort of challenge because things will never be as cut-and-dry in the workforce as they may be in classes.
2. Conceptually, I better understood how to connect quantitative environmental parameters (e.g. partitioning coefficients) to qualitative descriptions of how structure can impact environmental fate.
3. As someone who had not had a lot of experience with understanding chemical fate through atmospheric components, this class gave me a good foundation for understanding this field and helped me feel confident to pursue coursework in air quality engineering.
